facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 424 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 424 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 8, 1960 of Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 2650 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 8, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court in Civil Misc. Writ No. 2650 of 1956.

facts.text: Respondent is an ex-Zamindar.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent, an ex-Zamindar, was assessed to agricultural income-tax

facts.text: Respondent assessed to agricultural income-tax in assessment year 1360 F corresponding to 1952-53 on agricultural income of previous year 1359 F corresponding to 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent, an ex-Zamindar, was assessed to agricultural income-tax in the assessment year 1360 F companyresponding to 1952-53, on the basis of the agricultural income accruing in the previous year 1359 F companyresponding to 1951-52.

facts.text: Respondent did not pay the assessed tax and was assessed to a penalty, resulting in Rs. 868/- due for tax plus penalty.

anchor.surface_text: He did number pay the assessed tax and was further assessed to a penalty. In the result, Rs. 868/- were to be paid by him for tax plus penalty.

facts.text: Respondent's writ petition contending no liability to pay tax dismissed by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents writ petition companytending that he was number liable to pay tax was dismissed by the High Court.

facts.text: On July 24, 1956, respondent presented application to Agricultural Income-tax Assessing Officer, Allahabad, to accept Bonds of Rs. 850/- and Rs. 18/- cash in payment of tax dues.

anchor.surface_text: On July 24, 1956, the respondent presented an application to the Agricultural Income-tax Assessing Officer, Allahabad, stating that he had numberready cash to pay the dues and that he was therefore depositing Bonds of the value of Rs. 850/- and Rs. 18/- in cash and praying that the Bonds be accepted in payment of tax dues.

facts.text: Application of July 24, 1956 rejected by Assessing Officer stating no rule for acceptance of bonds.

anchor.surface_text: This application was rejected by an order stating that there was numberrule for the acceptance of those bonds and that they be returned to the applicant.

facts.text: On August 1, 1956, respondent made similar application to Collector.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1956, the respondent made a similar application to the Collector companyplaining that the Assessing Officer had numbervalid reason to refuse to take the Bonds when the Bonds were negotiable instruments.

facts.text: Collector's application rejected on August 24, 1956 on report that bonds not accepted for ag income-tax, not negotiable, no provision.

anchor.surface_text: This application was also rejected on a report of the Assessing Officer that the Bonds were number accepted in the settlement of agricultural income-tax dues, that they were number negotiable and that there was numberprovision in the Act for their acceptance.

facts.text: Respondent filed writ petition to Allahabad High Court for certiorari quashing orders, mandamus to accept bonds or deduct from rehabilitation grant, prohibition on coercive measures.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the respondent presented a writ petition to the High Court of Allahabad praying for the issue of a writ of certiorari quashing the orders of the Assessing Officer and the Collector, Allahabad, for the issue of a writ of mandamus directing them to accept the Bonds in lieu of the tax dues and, in any case, to deduct the amount from the rehabilitation grant due to the petitioner and for the issue of a writ of prohibition directing the opposite parties from adopting companyrcive measures for the realisation of the tax due from the petitioner.

facts.text: Writ grounds: bonds negotiable instruments, issued by govt so valid legal tender, r.8A requires deduction from interim compensation.

anchor.surface_text: The grounds mentioned in support of the prayers were that the Bonds were negotiable instruments and therefore refusal to accept them in payment of agricultural income-tax was illegal, that they, having been issued by Government, companyld number be subsequently refused they being perfectly valid legal tender and that in view or r. 8A of the Rules made under the Act the amount due for tax should have been deducted from the interim companypensation.

facts.text: Counter affidavit by Naib-Tehsildar Ag ITO: assessed from July 1,1952 on income July 1,1951, tax in four instalments, penalty Rs.43 per default.

anchor.surface_text: The companynter affidavit filed by the Naib-Tehsildar Agriculture Income-tax Officer, Allahabad, on behalf of the State, stated that the respondent was assessed to agricultural income-tax in the assessment year companymencing from July 1, 1952 on the income derived in the previous year companymencing from July 1, 1951, that the tax had to be paid in four instalments and in default of payment a penality of Rs. 43/- was imposed for each default in payment of the four instalments

facts.text: High Court held orders of Assessing Officer and Collector wrong due to ignorance of s.6(d) and r.8A.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the orders of the Agricultural Income-tax Assessing Officer and the Collector were wrong as the ground for refusing to accept the Bonds in payment of the tax on the ground that there was numberrule or statutory provision for their acceptance was incorrect and appeared to have been given in companyplete ignorance of the provision of law.

facts.text: High Court quashed Collector's order dated August 24, 1956 and directed to decide application afresh in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court therefore quashed the order of the Collector dated August 24, 1956 and directed him to decide the respondents application afresh in accordance with law as indicated above.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave and appeal against High Court order dated April 8, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter obtained special leave from this Court and appealed against the order of the High Court dated April 8, 1960.

facts.text: s.6(d) of the Act amended by s.3 of U.P. Act XVI of 1953 with retrospective effect from July 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: An amendment was made in this clause  d  by s. 3 of U.P. Act XVI of 1953, with retrospective effect from July 1, 1952.

facts.text: Rule 8A added by Notification No. 3266/I-A-1056-1954 dated August 17, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 8A was added to the rules by Notification No. 3266/I-A-1056-1954 dated August 17, 1954

facts.text: Supreme Court in Collector of Sultanpur v Raja Jagdish Prasad Sahi held s.6(d) applies to arrears assessed in 1360F on 1359F income and r.8A mandatory.

anchor.surface_text: It has been held by this Court in Collector of Sultanpur v Raja Jagdish Prasad Sahi 1  that the provisions of s. 6 d  of the Act would apply to arrears on account of agricultural income-tax assessed in 1360F on the basis of agricultural income during the year 1359F and that the provisions of r. 8A are mandatory.

facts.text: Compensation payable in cash or bonds or partly as per s.68 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 68 of the Act provides that the companypensation under the Act shall be payable in cash or in bonds or partly in cash and partly in bonds as may be prescribed.

facts.text: Delivery of bonds to intermediary satisfies compensation claim per s.68.

anchor.surface_text: It is clear therefore that the delivery of Bonds to the intermediary is in payment of the companypensation. The claim for companypensation is thus satisfied when the companypensation has been paid in accordance with the provisions of s. 68.

facts.text: Bonds are negotiable but not legal tender, no obligation to accept in payment of dues.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Bonds are negotiable does number make them legal tender and does number make it obligatory on anyone, including Government, to accept them in payment of any dues.

facts.text: Neither s.6(d) nor r.8A provide for acceptance of bonds in payment of agricultural income-tax.

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 d  of the Act and r. 8A of the rules do number. as already stated, provide for the receipt of agricultural income-tax in the form of Bonds.

facts.text: Rule 62 provided compensation paid in negotiable Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds prior to Nov 29, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 62 as it stood prior to November 29, 1956, provided that the companypensation would be paid in negotiable bonds which would be described as Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds.

facts.text: Bonds bear interest from date of vesting, paid in equated annual installments over 40 years.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 63 as it then stood provided that the Bonds would be issued in specified denominations and would bear interest at the specified rate on the principal that had become payable calculated from the date of vesting. Rule 64 provided that interest together with the principal of a Bond would be paid in equated annual installments except for the last, as described in Appendix IV during the period of 40 years beginning from the date of vesting

issues.text: whether Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds shortly termed Bonds issued by the U.P. Government to intermediaries in payment of compensation payable on the basis of their rights under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950 U.P. Act I of 1951, hereinafter referred to as the Act, have to be accepted by the appropriate authorities in payment of the agricultural income-tax due from them

anchor.surface_text: This appeal, by special leave, raises the question whether Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds  shortly termed Bonds  issued by the U.P. Government to intermediaries in payment of companypensation payable on the basis of their rights under the Uttar Pradesh Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950  U.P. Act I of 1951 , hereinafter referred to as the Act, have to be accepted by the appropriate authorities in payment of the agricultural income-tax due from them.

issues.text: whether neither s. 6 d of the Act nor r. 8A provides that Bonds can be accepted in payment of agricultural income-tax

whether r. 8A makes it mandatory for the Agricultural Income-tax Officer to realise the agricultural income tax due from the compensation payable and that compensation continues to be payable till the Bonds are actually encashed
whether the compensation payable to the intermediary continues to remain payable even after the compensation Bonds had been delivered to him
whether the Bonds are legal tender and obligatory on Government to accept them in payment of any dues

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following binding precedent of this Court in Collector of Sultanpur v Raja Jagdish Prasad Sahi

holdings.text: neither s. 6(d) nor r. 8A provide that Bonds must or can be accepted in payment of tax on agricultural income

anchor.surface_text: It is clear from the above provisions that neither s. 6 d  number r. 8A provide that Bonds must or can be accepted in payment of tax on agricultural income. It has been held by this Court in Collector of Sultanpur v Raja Jagdish Prasad Sahi

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s.6(d) and r.8A after quoting their provisions

holdings.text: r. 8A is not inconsistent with the provisions of s. 6(d)

anchor.surface_text: It is not urged for the appellant that r. 8A is inconsistent with the provisions of s. 6 d  which provides that arrears of tax may be realised from the compensation payable and therefore appears to give a discretion to. the authorities to realise the arrears of tax from the compensation payable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No argument made on inconsistency and provisions read harmoniously

holdings.text: the delivery of Bonds to the intermediary is in payment of the compensation. The claim for compensation is thus satisfied when the compensation has been paid in accordance with the provisions of s. 68

anchor.surface_text: Section 68 of the Act provides that the compensation under the Act shall be payable in cash or in bonds or partly in cash and partly in bonds as may be prescribed. It is clear therefore that the delivery of Bonds to the intermediary is in payment of the compensation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68 expressly provides for payment in bonds or cash; delivery constitutes satisfaction of claim

holdings.text: We do not agree with the contention for the respondent that the compensation payable to the intermediary continues to remain payable even after the compensation Bonds had been delivered to him
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.68 payment in bonds satisfies claim; supported by rules 62-65 on bond delivery and encashment schedule

holdings.text: These rules show that the compensation does not remain payable after the delivery of the Bonds and that the Bonds could not be cashed before the due date for their encashment

anchor.surface_text: Rule 62 as it stood prior to November 29, 1956, provided that the compensation would be paid in negotiable bonds which would be described as Zamindari Abolition Compensation Bonds. Rule 63 as it then stood provided that the Bonds would be issued in specified denominations and would bear interest

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules 62,63,64,65 detail bond issuance, interest, repayment schedule post-delivery, prohibiting early encashment

holdings.text: The fact that the Bonds are negotiable does not make them legal tender and does not make it obligatory on anyone, including Government, to accept them in payment of any dues

anchor.surface_text: The fact that the Bonds are negotiable does number make them legal tender and does number make it obligatory on anyone, including Government, to accept them in payment of any dues.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Negotiability allows transfer but does not confer legal tender status requiring acceptance

holdings.text: Section 6(d) of the Act and r. 8A of the rules do not, as already stated, provide for the receipt of agricultural income-tax in the form of Bonds

anchor.surface_text: Section 6 d  of the Act and r. 8A of the rules do number. as already stated, provide for the receipt of agricultural income-tax in the form of Bonds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Reiteration of textual absence in provisions for bond acceptance as tax payment

anchor.surface_text: When the companypensation payable to an intermediary has been paid in the form of cash or Bonds, that companypensation ceases to be payable. Section 6 d  of the Act and r. 8A of the rules do number. as already stated, provide for the receipt
